channel.title: Australian school maths
channel.description: Recent content on Australian school maths

item.description:
$ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $
$ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $
$ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

$ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $
$ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $
$ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

Working with Functions #


Concepts #

Notes #

Spreadsheets #

WorkingWithFunctions


Formulas #


$a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$
$a^m \div a^n = \dfrac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$
$(a^m)^n = a^{m \times n}$
$(ab)^n = a^nb^n$
$\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^n = \dfrac{a^n}{b^n}$
$a^0=1$
$a^{-n}=\dfrac{1}{a^n}$
$\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^{-n} = \left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n$
$a^{\frac{m}{n}} =\sqrt[n]{a^m}$
$ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $
$ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $
$ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

$ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $
$ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

$ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $

$P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$
$^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$
$0! = 1$
$^n P_n = n!$
$^n P_0 = 1$
Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$
$^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$
$(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$
$ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $
$ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $
$ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $
$ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $
$ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $
$ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $
Items on formula sheet are highlighted
$P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$
$^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$
$0! = 1$
$^n P_n = n!$
$^n P_0 = 1$
Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$
$^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$
$(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$
$ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $
$ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $
$ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $
$ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $
$ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $
$ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

Still need to complete the bulk of this section #

The below is the section that is muddled in with Ch 8 Calculus

Multiple roots if polynomial equations #

If P(x) = 0 has a multiple root at x=k then P(k) = P(k) = 0
Proof of above

Derivative Equivalent integral Comment
$y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ \text{ where } n \neq -1 $ When n = -1 follow the integration rules for $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$
$y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$
$y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$
$y=\sin f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\cos f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$
$y=\cos f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -f'(x)\sin f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$
$y=\tan f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = \tan f(x) + c$
$y=e^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) e^{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$
$y=\ln f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ Stictly speaking these integral and derivative formulas are not exact mirrors but are recorded here as presented in the syllabus. The scope of the derivative equation is limited to positive values of f(x) while the integral equation covers both positive and negative values of f(x). The derivative equation could also be rewritten with an absolute value.
$y=a^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = (\ln a)f'(x)a^{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation.
$y=log _{a} f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value?
Items on formula sheet are highlighted

Logarithms and Exponentials #


Concepts #

Notes #




Formulas #


$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$
$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

Derivative Equivalent integral Comment
$y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ \text{ where } n \neq -1 $ When n = -1 follow the integration rules for $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$
$y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$
$y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$
$y=\sin f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\cos f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$
$y=\cos f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -f'(x)\sin f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$
$y=\tan f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = \tan f(x) + c$
$y=e^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) e^{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$
$y=\ln f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ Stictly speaking these integral and derivative formulas are not exact mirrors but are recorded here as presented in the syllabus. The scope of the derivative equation is limited to positive values of f(x) while the integral equation covers both positive and negative values of f(x). The derivative equation could also be rewritten with an absolute value.
$y=a^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = (\ln a)f'(x)a^{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation.
$y=log _{a} f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value?
$y=\sin^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} f(x) + c$
$ y = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{\sqrt{a^2 - (f(x))^2}} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$
$y=\cos^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}f(x) + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}f(x) +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$y=\cos^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$y=\tan^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2} dx = \ \tan^{-1} f(x) + c$
$y=\tan^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$
Items on formula sheet are highlighted

$y=\sin^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} f(x) + c$
$ y = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{\sqrt{a^2 - (f(x))^2}} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$
$y=\cos^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}f(x) + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}f(x) +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$y=\cos^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$y=\tan^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2} dx = \ \tan^{-1} f(x) + c$
$y=\tan^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$

$ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $
$ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $
$ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

$ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $
$ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $
$ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $
$ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $
$ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $
$\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$
$|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$
$|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $
$\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $
$\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $
$ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $
$ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $
$ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $
$ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $
$ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $
$ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$
$ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$
$\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$
$\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$

Logarithms and Exponentials #


Concepts #

Notes #




Formulas #


$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$
$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

Proof by Mathematical Induction #


Notes #

  • Can be utilised to prove a statement true for all positive integers, n

  • Step 1: Show that the statement is true for n=1

  • Step 2: Assume that the statement is true for some positive integer n = k

  • Step 3: Using the assumption prove that the statement is also true for the next integer n=k+1

  • Conclusion: State why the statement is true for all positive integers $n \ge 1$ Don’t forget this!

Derivative Equivalent integral Comment
$y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ \text{ where } n \neq -1 $ When n = -1 follow the integration rules for $ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx$
$y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$
$ {\Large\int} u \dfrac{dv}{dx} dx=uv-{\Large\int}v \dfrac {du}{dx}dx$
$y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$
$y=\sin f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\cos f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$
$y=\cos f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = -f'(x)\sin f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$
$y=\tan f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = \tan f(x) + c$
$y=e^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = f'(x) e^{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$
$y=\ln f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$ Stictly speaking these integral and derivative formulas are not exact mirrors but are recorded here as presented in the syllabus. The scope of the derivative equation is limited to positive values of f(x) while the integral equation covers both positive and negative values of f(x). The derivative equation could also be rewritten with an absolute value.
$y=a^{f(x)} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = (\ln a)f'(x)a^{f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$ ln a is a constant therefore can be removed from the integral it can go on the other side of the intergral equation when compared to the derivative equation.
$y=log _{a} f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$ Is this integral expression correct, in particular the absolute value?
$y=\sin^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} f(x) + c$
$ y = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{\sqrt{a^2 - (f(x))^2}} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$
$y=\cos^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}f(x) + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}f(x) +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$y=\cos^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$y=\tan^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2}$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2} dx = \ \tan^{-1} f(x) + c$
$y=\tan^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$

$y=\tan^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$

$ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $
$ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $
$ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

$ |x| + |y| \ge |x+y|, \forall \; x, y \in \mathbb{R}$

Formulas #


$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$
$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

Trigonometry and Measure of Angles #


Concepts #

  • angle of elevation
  • angle of depression
  • true bearing
  • compass bearing
  • amplitude
  • period
  • phase

Notes #

Trigonometry #

Naming convention uses upper case letter for angle and equivalent lower case letter for the side opposite the angle.

Use sine rule

  • to find a side given 2 angles and one side (AAS)
  • To find an angle given 2 sides and a non included angle (SSA)
    • This is the ambiguous case (there are 2 possible solutions, one accute and one obtuse angle)
    • SSA is not a proof of congruence given the potential for an ambiguous solution
    • In questions check that the obtuse solution does not result in the known angle + the calculated angle exceding 180 degrees. In this case the obtuse angle is not a valid solution

Use the cosine rule

Trigonometry #

Naming convention uses upper case letter for angle and equivalent lower case letter for the side opposite the angle.

Use sine rule

  • to find a side given 2 angles and one side (AAS)
  • To find an angle given 2 sides and a non included angle (SSA)
    • This is the ambiguous case (there are 2 possible solutions, one accute and one obtuse angle)
    • SSA is not a proof of congruence given the potential for an ambiguous solution
    • In questions check that the obtuse solution does not result in the known angle + the calculated angle exceding 180 degrees. In this case the obtuse angle is not a valid solution

Use the cosine rule

$a = \ddot x = \dfrac{dv}{dt} = \dfrac{d^{2}x}{dt^2}$
$\dfrac{dN}{dt} = kn \text{ is satisfied by } N(t) = Ae^{kt}$
$\dfrac{dN}{dt} = k(N-p) \text{ is satisfied by } N(t) = P + Ae^{kt}$

Inverse Trigonometric Functions #


Concepts #

Notes #

The graph of an inverse function is a reflection of the original function in the line y=x. (the y-value and x-values of the original graph are switched to obtain the inverse graph)

The domain of the original function needs to be restricted before converting into the inverse fucntion to ensure that the result is a function, that is one value of y for each value of x. This means that a horizontal line can cross the original function at only one point so that the inverse funciton passes a similar test with a vertical line.

Arithmetic sequence Geometric sequence
Recursive definition $ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $ $T_n = rT_{n-1}$
n-th term $T_n = a + (n-1)d$ $T_n = ar^{n-1}$
Sum of first n terms $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}[2a + (n-1)d] = \dfrac{n}{2}(a+l)$ $S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
Limiting sum $S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

$ {\Large\int} f'(x)[f(x)]^n dx = \dfrac{1}{n+1}[f(x)]^{n+1} + c $ $ \text{ where } n \neq -1 $
$ {\Large\int_{a}^{b}} f(x) dx \approx \dfrac{b-a} {2n} {\Large\{} f(a) + f(b) + 2 {\Large[} f(x_1)+...+f(x_{n-1}){\Large ]} {\Large\}}$ $ \text { where } a=x_0 \text{ and } b=x_n $
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\cos f(x)dx = \sin f(x) + c$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sin f(x)dx = -\cos f(x) + c$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)\sec^2 f(x)dx = \tan f(x) + c$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)e^{f(x)}dx = e^{f(x)} + c$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{f(x)}dx = \ln|f(x)| + c$
$ {\Large\int} f'(x)a^{f(x)}dx = \dfrac{a^f(x)}{\ln a} +c$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)}{(\ln a) f(x)} = \log_{a} |f(x)| + c$
$ {\Large\int}_b^a f(x)dx = F(b)-F(a) \text{, where F(x) is the anti-derivative of f(x)}$
$F'(x) = \dfrac{d}{dx} {\Large\int}_a^x f(t)dt = f(x) \text{ (the Fundamental Therom of Calculus)}$

Graphing Techniques #


Concepts #

Notes #

Trigonometric Functions and Graphs #


Notes #

  • Understand the transformation of functions in the form y=kf(a(x+b))+c, where f(x) is a trigonometric function such as sin x, cos x etc.
  • Be able to determine the domain and range of the transformed function
  • The impact of the transforation on amplitude, phase and center are set out in Year 11 Advanced, Trigonometric Functions.
  • Note that amplitude is a measure from centre to top (or bottom) of graph. NOT top to bottom.
  • Note that domain refers to the values that can be allocated to $x$. For example if $y=\sin 3x$ has a domain of $[0, \pi]$ tht means that $3x$ will have values between $0$ and $3\pi$

Logistic equation option 1: $\frac{dP}{dt} = kP(N-P)$

Logistic equation option 2:$\frac{dP}{dt} = kP(1-\frac{P}{N})$
$y=\sin^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$ y = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)}{\sqrt{a^2 - (f(x))^2}} $
$y=\cos^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} }$
$y=\cos^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} }$
$y=\tan^{-1}f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2}$
$y=\tan^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} $
$ \text{Function and its inverse} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} \times \dfrac{dx}{dy} = 1, \text{ or } \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{1}{\dfrac{dx}{dy}} $

WorkingWithFunctions


Formulas #


$a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$
$a^m \div a^n = \dfrac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$
$(a^m)^n = a^{m \times n}$
$(ab)^n = a^nb^n$
$\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^n = \dfrac{a^n}{b^n}$
$a^0=1$
$a^{-n}=\dfrac{1}{a^n}$
$\left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^{-n} = \left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n$
$a^{\frac{m}{n}} =\sqrt[n]{a^m}$
$ \sqrt{xy} = \sqrt{x} \times \sqrt{y} $
$ \sqrt{\dfrac{x}{y}} = \dfrac{\sqrt{x}}{\sqrt{y}} $
$ (\sqrt{x})^2 = \sqrt{x^2} = x \text{ for } x\ge 0 $

Arithmetic sequence Geometric sequence
Recursive definition $ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $ $T_n = rT_{n-1}$
n-th term $T_n = a + (n-1)d$ $T_n = ar^{n-1}$
Sum of first n terms $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}[2a + (n-1)d] = \dfrac{n}{2}(a+l)$ $S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
Limiting sum $S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

Recursive definition $ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $ $T_n = rT_{n-1}$
n-th term $T_n = a + (n-1)d$ $T_n = ar^{n-1}$

Limiting sum $S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

$a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$
$a^m \div a^n = \dfrac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$
$(a^m)^n = a^{m \times n}$
$(ab)^n = a^nb^n$

$ i = \sqrt{-1}$
$ z = a + ib$
$\text{ mod z} =|z| = \sqrt{a^2+b^2} $
$\tan \theta = \dfrac{b}{a} \text{ where } \theta \text{ equals arg z in interval } (-\pi, \pi] \text{Dont confuse with angle of a position vector which ranges from 0 to 360 degrees}$
$z = r (\cos \theta + i \sin \theta)$
$ z_1z_2 = r_1 r_2[\cos(\theta_1 + \theta_2) + i \sin(\theta_1 + \theta_2)]$
$ \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} = \dfrac{r_1}{ r_2}[\cos(\theta_1 - \theta_2) + i \sin(\theta_1 - \theta_2)], z_2 \ne 0$
$ z^n = r^n(\cos n \theta + i \sin n \theta)$
$ z^{-1} = r^{-1}(\cos \theta - i \sin \theta), z \ne 0$
$ z^{-n} = r^{-n}(\cos -n \theta + i \sin -n \theta), z \ne 0, n \in \mathbb{Z}$
$ z_1z_2...z_n = r_1r_2...r_n[\cos(\theta_1+\theta_2+...\theta_n) + i\sin(\theta_1+\theta_2+...\theta_n)]$
$ |z_1||z_2| = |z_1z_2| \text{ and arg } z_1z_2 = { arg } z_1 + { arg } z_2$
$ \dfrac{|z_1|}{|z_2|} = \bigg| \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} \bigg| \text{ and arg } \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} = { arg } z_1 - { arg } z_2$
$ |z|^n = |z^n| \text{ and arg } z^n = n \times \text{arg z for } n \in \mathbb{Z}$
$ |z^{-1}| = \dfrac{1}{|z|} \text { and arg } z^{-1} = -\text {arg z}, z\ne 0$
$ |z^{-n}| = \dfrac{1}{|z|^n} \text { and arg } z^{-n} = \text {-n arg z}, z\ne 0 \text { for } n \in \mathbb{Z}$
$ |z_1||z_2||z_3|...|z_n| = |z_1z_2z_3...z_n| \text { and arg } z_1z_2z_3...z_n = { arg } z_1 + { arg } z_2 + ...+ { arg } z_n \text { where } n \in \mathbb{Z}$
$ \text{ If } z = \cos \theta + i\sin \theta \text{, then } z^{-1} = \overline{z} \text{ (only applies when modulus = 1)} $
$ z\overline{z} = |z|^2 \text{ and arg } z\overline{z} = 0 $
$ |\overline{z}| = |z| \text{ and arg } \overline{z} = -{arg } z $
$ \overline{z_1} + \overline{z_2} = \overline{z_1 + z_2} $
$ \overline{z_1} \,\, \overline{z_2} = \overline{z_1 z_2} $
$ z + \overline{z} = 2Re(z) $
$ z - \overline{z} = 2Im(z) $
$ {|z+w| \le |z| + |w|} \text{ (the triangle inequality where z and w are complex numbers)} $
$ e^{i\theta} = \cos \theta + i \sin \theta, \text{ where }\theta \in \mathbb{R} \text{ (This is Euler's formula and represents the exponential form of a complex number)}$
$ e^{i\pi} = -1 $
$ z = a+ib = r(\cos \theta + i \sin \theta) = re^{i \theta}$
$ [r(\cos \theta + i \sin \theta)]^n = r^n(\cos n\theta + i\sin n\theta) = r^ne^{in \theta}$
$(e ^ {i \theta})^n = e ^ {in \theta} $
$z^n + \dfrac{1}{z^n} = 2 \cos n \theta $
$z^n - \dfrac{1}{z^n} = 2i \sin n \theta $
$ i = 1(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{2} + i \sin \dfrac{\pi}{2})$

Further Work with Vectors #


Concepts #

  • parametric equations

  • $\underset{\sim}{\hat{v}}$ is the unit vector of $\underset{\sim}{v}$

Note that concepts covered in Year 12 Ext 1 are not repeated above

Notes #

General

  • Unit vectors i, j, and k represent directions x, y, and z respectively

  • The vector from $A(x_1, y_1, z_1)$ to $B(x_12 y_2, z_2)$
    $= \vec{AB} $
    $= (x_2-x_1)i + (y_2-y1)j+(z_2-z1)k$

Geometry proofs using vectors

$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$
$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

$\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$
$\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$
$\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x \text{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$
$\tan(\tan^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$
$\tan^{-1}(\tan x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $
$\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $
$\tan^{-1}(-x) = -\tan^{-1}x $
$\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$
$\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$
$\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$
$\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$
$\tan(A+B) = \dfrac{\tan A + \tan B}{1-\tan A \tan B}$
$\tan(A-B) = \dfrac{\tan A - \tan B}{1+\tan A \tan B}$
$\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$
$\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$
$\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$
$\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$
$\tan 2A = \dfrac{2\tan A}{1-\tan^2 A}$
$ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$ \tan A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$
$\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]$
$\sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]$
$\cos A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]$

Rates of Change #

Rates of change with respect to time #

Zero displacement, when a particle is at the origin that is x = 0

Velocity

  • rate of change of displacement, $v = \dot x = \dfrac{dx}{dt}$

  • If a particle is moving to the right then velocity is positive, to the left velocity is negative

  • Zero velocity = when a particle is not moving

$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$
$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

$ \text{Mean} = \dfrac{\text{Sum of scores}}{\text{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $
$ \text{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} \text{th score} $ $ \text{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $
$ \text{Range = highest score - lowest score} $
$ \text{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $
$\text{An outlier is a score with} $ $ \text { less than } Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \text { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR $
$ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $
$P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) \text {(for continuous probability distributions})$
$F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx \text { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$
$P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$
$P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$
$f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \text{ for } a \leq x \leq b \text { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$
$z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $

Notes #

Trigonometry #

Naming convention uses upper case letter for angle and equivalent lower case letter for the side opposite the angle.

Use sine rule

  • to find a side given 2 angles and one side (AAS)
  • To find an angle given 2 sides and a non included angle (SSA)
    • This is the ambiguous case (there are 2 possible solutions, one accute and one obtuse angle)
    • SSA is not a proof of congruence given the potential for an ambiguous solution
    • In questions check that the obtuse solution does not result in the known angle + the calculated angle exceding 180 degrees. In this case the obtuse angle is not a valid solution

Use the cosine rule

Differential Calculus #


Notes #

Differentiation of trigonometric, exponential and logarithmic functions #

Refer formulas below (the non-chain rule versions). Note cases requiring proof.

NB The trig derivative rules work on radians, not degrees. If a question is in degrees it first needs to be converted into radians. Convert back to degrees in final step if required.

Rules of differentiation #

Apply product, quotient and chain rules to differentiate the “simpler” versions of the function.

$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$

$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$

Volumes formed by rotation about the x-axis = $V=\pi \int_a^b y^2 dx$
Volumes formed by rotation about the y-axis = $V=\pi \int_a^b x^2 dy$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} f(x) + c$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } dx = \sin^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {1 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}f(x) + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}f(x) +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$ {\Large\int} - \dfrac{f'(x)} {\sqrt {a^2 - (f(x))^2} } = \cos^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c \text{ or } -\sin^{-1}\dfrac{f(x)}{a} +c$ $ \text{Note the constant c will have different values with these two options} $
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {1 + (f(x))^2} dx = \ \tan^{-1} f(x) + c$
$ {\Large\int} \dfrac{f'(x)} {a^2 + (f(x))^2} dx = \dfrac{1}{a} \tan^{-1} \dfrac{f(x)}{a} + c$

Arithmetic vs geometric sequences #


  Arithmetic sequence Geometric sequence
Recursive definition $ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $ $T_n = rT_{n-1}$
n-th term $T_n = a + (n-1)d$ $T_n = ar^{n-1}$
Sum of first n terms $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}[2a + (n-1)d] = \dfrac{n}{2}(a+l)$ $S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
Limiting sum $S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

Notes #

Auxiliary angles

The auxiliary angle method can be utilsed to reduce an expression in the format $\pm a\cos x \pm b \sin x $ into $r \cos (x \pm \alpha)$ or $r \sin (x \pm \alpha)$. In these scenarios, $\alpha$ is known as the auxiliary angle.

The above simpliciation can be useful in solving equations or sketching graphs.

Examples of auxiliary angles are incuded in the formulas below for example:
$a \sin x + b \cos x = r \sin(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$

$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$
$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

$\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{u}$
$(\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v}) + \underset{\sim}{w} = \underset{\sim}{u} + (\underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{w} )$
$\underset{\sim}{u} + 0 = \underset{\sim}{u}$
$|\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v}| \le |\underset{\sim}{u}| + |\underset{\sim}{v}|$
$|r| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 + z_1z_2 = |\underset{\sim}{u}|\underset{\sim}{v}| \cos \theta$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} . \underset{\sim}{u}$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . (\underset{\sim}{v} +\underset{\sim}{w}) = \underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{w}$
$r = \underset{\sim}{a} + \lambda \underset{\sim}{b}$
Items on formula sheet are highlighted
$\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{u}$
$(\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v}) + \underset{\sim}{w} = \underset{\sim}{u} + (\underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{w} )$
$\underset{\sim}{u} + 0 = \underset{\sim}{u}$
$|\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v}| \le |\underset{\sim}{u}| + |\underset{\sim}{v}|$
$|r| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 + z_1z_2 = |\underset{\sim}{u}|\underset{\sim}{v}| \cos \theta$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} . \underset{\sim}{u}$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . (\underset{\sim}{v} +\underset{\sim}{w}) = \underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{w}$
$r = \underset{\sim}{a} + \lambda \underset{\sim}{b}$

$ y=f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} =\lim\limits_{h \to 0} \dfrac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{h} $
$ y=kx \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} =k $
$ y=k \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} =0 $
$ y=x^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} =nx^{n-1} $
$ y=kx^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} =knx^{n-1} $
$ y=kf(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} =kf'(x) $
$ y=f(x) + g(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} =f'(x) + g'(x) $
$y=f(x)^n \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx}=nf'(x)[f(x)]^{n-1}$
$y=uv \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = u\dfrac{dv}{dx} + v\dfrac{du}{dx}$
$y=\dfrac{u}{v} \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{v\dfrac{du}{dx} - u\dfrac{dv}{dx}}{v^2}$
$y=g(u) \text { where } u = f(x) \,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\,\, \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{dy}{du} \times \dfrac{du}{dx} \text { (the chain rule)}$

Logarithms and Exponentials #


Concepts #

Notes #




Formulas #


$\log_a{(xy)} = \log_a{x} + log_a{y}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{x}{y}\right)} = \log_a{x} - log_a{y}$
$\log_a{x^n} = n\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{\left(\dfrac{1}{x}\right)} = -\log_a{x}$
$\log_a{x} = \dfrac{\log_b{x}}{\log_b{a}}$

Working with Combinatorics #


Concepts #

  • arrangements
  • fundamental counting principle, also known as the multiplication principle
  • pigeonhole principle
  • generalised pigeonhole principle
  • ordered selections
  • unordered selections
  • factorial
  • permutations
  • combinations
  • binomial expansion
  • Pascal’s triangle and binomial coefficients
  • Pascal’s triangle identity

Notes #

  • $ n!$ is the number of ways of selecting n objects with no replacement or repetition. Order is important.

  • Permutations = ordered

  • $^nP_r$ is the number of ways of making an ordered selection or r objects from a total of n objects.

$ P(E) = \dfrac{n(E)}{n(S)} $
$P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B) $
$P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)$
$P(\overline{E}) = 1 - P(E)$
$ P(A|B) = \dfrac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)} \text{, where } P(B) \neq 0 $
$ P(X=x) = \dfrac{1}{n} \text {applies only to uniform proability distributions with n values} $
$ E(X) =\sum xp(x)$
$ E(X) = \mu $
$ \sigma^{2} = Var(X) = \sum(x-\mu)^{2}p(x)$
$ Var(X) = E[(x-\mu)^2]$
$ Var(X) = \sum[x^2p(x)] - \mu^2$
$ Var(X) = E(X^2) - \mu^2$
$ \sigma = \sqrt{Var(X)}$
$ \text{Mean} = \dfrac{\text{Sum of scores}}{\text{Total number of scores}} = \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum{x}}{n} $
$ \text{The median of n scores is the } \dfrac{n+1}{2} \text{th score} $ $ \text{if n is even the median is the average of the two middle scores to the left and the right of } \dfrac{n+1}{2} $
$ \text{Range = highest score - lowest score} $
$ \text{Interquartile range = Q3 - Q1} $
$\text{An outlier is a score with} $ $ \text { less than } Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \text { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR $
$ \overline{x} = \dfrac{\sum fx}{\sum f} $
$P(a < X < b) = P(a \leq X \leq b) \text {(for continuous probability distributions})$
$F(x) = P(X\leq x) = {\Large\int}^x_a f(x)dx \text { (for continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b] and F(x) is the cumulative density function})$
$P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$
$P(a \leq X \leq b) = {\Large\int}_a^b f(x)dx$
$f(x) = \dfrac{1}{b-a} \text{ for } a \leq x \leq b \text { (Uniform continuous probability distributions, where f(x) is a probability distribution function defined in the domain [a,b]})$
$z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $

$ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $
$T_n = a + (n-1)d$
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}[2a + (n-1)d] = \dfrac{n}{2}(a+l)$
$T_n = rT_{n-1}$
$T_n = ar^{n-1}$
$S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
$S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

Arithmetic vs geometric sequences #


  Arithmetic sequence Geometric sequence
Recursive definition $ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $ $T_n = rT_{n-1}$
n-th term $T_n = a + (n-1)d$ $T_n = ar^{n-1}$
Sum of first n terms $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}[2a + (n-1)d] = \dfrac{n}{2}(a+l)$ $S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
Limiting sum $S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

$\text{An outlier is a score with} $ $ \text { less than } Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR $ $ \text { or more than than } Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR $

$P(X \leq r) = {\Large\int}_a^r f(x)dx$

$z = \dfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} $

Proof by Mathematical Induction #


Notes #

  • Can be utilised to prove a statement true for all positive integers, n

  • Step 1: Show that the statement is true for n=1

  • Step 2: Assume that the statement is true for some positive integer n = k

  • Step 3: Using the assumption prove that the statement is also true for the next integer n=k+1

  • Conclusion: State why the statement is true for all positive integers $n \ge 1$ Don’t forget this!

Further Calculus Skills #


Concepts #

Notes #

Integration by substitution #

This can be useful when integrals don’t follow any of the other standard rules.

With an equation like $\frac{du}{dx}=3$, while $\frac{du}{dx}$ is not a true fraction, certain fraction-like operations do apply and therefore above can be rewritten as $dx = \frac{1}{3}du$

General approach:

  • Identify a portion of the equation that needs to be integrated and set equal to u
  • Differentiate above to obtain an equation in the format $\frac{du}{dx}$ = something
  • Solve for dx (make dx subject of equation) so that the dx in the original integral can be replaced with an expression in terms of du.
  • In some cases it may be convenvient to substitute with x as the subject of the equation rather than u, for example $x = u^2-1$, in this case calculate $\frac{dx}{du}$ rather than $\frac{du}{dx}$
  • substitute the x’s and dx in the original equation with u’s and du
  • calculate the integral in terms of u
  • for indefinite integrals replace the u’s with expression in terms of x in the final step
  • for definite integrals recalculate the lower and upper limits by substituting the original integral lower and upper limits into x in the formula for u as a function of x. That way when the integral is calculated in terms of u, there is no need to rework back to x.
  • My undesrtanding is that HSC answers follow a simplified approach for convenience with relation to square roots arising from integration by susbstitution. For example if substituting with $x=u^2$, then u is simply taken as $\sqrt{x}$, rather than $\pm \sqrt{x}$

Integrals in the form $\sin^2nx$ and $\cos^2ns$ #

Prove and use the below 2 identities in order to solve integrals in the form of $\sin^2nx$ and $\cos^2ns$:

Trigonometry and Measure of Angles #


Concepts #

  • angle of elevation
  • angle of depression
  • true bearing
  • compass bearing
  • amplitude
  • period
  • phase

Notes #

Trigonometry #

Naming convention uses upper case letter for angle and equivalent lower case letter for the side opposite the angle.

Use sine rule

  • to find a side given 2 angles and one side (AAS)
  • To find an angle given 2 sides and a non included angle (SSA)
    • This is the ambiguous case (there are 2 possible solutions, one accute and one obtuse angle)
    • SSA is not a proof of congruence given the potential for an ambiguous solution
    • In questions check that the obtuse solution does not result in the known angle + the calculated angle exceding 180 degrees. In this case the obtuse angle is not a valid solution

Use the cosine rule

Further Integration #


Concepts #

Notes #

Integration by substitution #

This is an extension of this topic as covered in Year 12 Ext 1.

Hints:

  • When substituting with say $u=\sqrt{x}$ it is not necessary to replace every single $\sqrt{x}$ with u. One of the cases can be left as $\sqrt{x}$ to cross cancel with value in the “derivative” portion of the equation, for exmple where $dx = 5 \sqrt{x}$

$ E(X) = \mu $
$ \sigma^{2} = Var(X) = \sum(x-\mu)^{2}p(x)$
$ Var(X) = E[(x-\mu)^2]$
$ Var(X) = \sum[x^2p(x)] - \mu^2$
$ Var(X) = E(X^2) - \mu^2$
$ \sigma = \sqrt{Var(X)}$
Items where proofs required are highlighted

Arithmetic vs geometric sequences #


  Arithmetic sequence Geometric sequence
Recursive definition $ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $ $T_n = rT_{n-1}$
n-th term $T_n = a + (n-1)d$ $T_n = ar^{n-1}$
Sum of first n terms $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}[2a + (n-1)d] = \dfrac{n}{2}(a+l)$ $S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
Limiting sum $S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

$\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$

Notes #

  • Properties of binomial distribution:

    • fixed number of trials
    • there are only 2 outcomes: success or failure
    • each trial is independent
    • Probabilities are the same for each trial

  • Share of a binomial distribution:

    • p<0.5 : positively skewed
    • p=0.5 : normal / symmetrical
    • p>0.5 : negatively skewed

  • Be able to represent a Bernoulli distribution as a :

$P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$

$ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $
$ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $
$ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $
$ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $
$ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $
$ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

$P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$
$^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$
$0! = 1$
$^n P_n = n!$
$^n P_0 = 1$
Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$
$^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$
$(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$
$ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $
$ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $
$ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $
$ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $
$ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $
$ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

Notes #

Trigonometry #

Naming convention uses upper case letter for angle and equivalent lower case letter for the side opposite the angle.

Use sine rule

  • to find a side given 2 angles and one side (AAS)
  • To find an angle given 2 sides and a non included angle (SSA)
    • This is the ambiguous case (there are 2 possible solutions, one accute and one obtuse angle)
    • SSA is not a proof of congruence given the potential for an ambiguous solution
    • In questions check that the obtuse solution does not result in the known angle + the calculated angle exceding 180 degrees. In this case the obtuse angle is not a valid solution

Use the cosine rule

$ \vec{AB} + \vec{BC} = \vec{AC} $
$ |\underset{\sim}{u}| = |x\underset{\sim}{i} + y\underset{\sim}{j}| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2} $
$ \underset{\sim}{a} + (-\underset{\sim}{a}) =0 $
$ \vec{AB} - \vec{AD} = \vec{AB} + \vec{DA} = \vec{DA} + \vec{AB} = \vec{DB} $
$ \text{The unit vector parallel to } \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} * \dfrac{1}{|\underset{\sim}{v}|} $
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 + a_2 \\b_1 + b_2 \end{pmatrix} $
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a_1 - a_2 \\b_1 - b_2 \end{pmatrix} $
$\lambda \begin{pmatrix} a \\b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda a \\ \lambda b \end{pmatrix}$
$|\underset{\sim}{u}| = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}$
$|\vec{XY}| = \sqrt{(x_2-x_1)^2 + (y_2-y_1)^2}$
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 + a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1+b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $
$\begin{pmatrix} a_1 \\b_1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} a_2 \\b_2 \end{pmatrix} = (a_1 - a_2)\underset{\sim}{i} + (b_1-b_2)\underset{\sim}{j} $
$\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}|\cos\theta = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 $
$\underset{\sim}{v}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{v}|^2 $
$ \text{perpendicular vectors: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = 0 $
$ \text{parallel vectors like directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = |\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $
$ \text{parallel vectors unlike directions: }\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v} = -|\underset{\sim}{u}||\underset{\sim}{v}| $
$ P_{\underset{\sim}{u}}\underset{\sim}{v} = \dfrac{\underset{\sim}{u}.\underset{\sim}{v}}{|\underset{\sim}{u}|^2} \underset{\sim}{u} $
$ \underset{\sim}{u} = (r\cos\theta, r\sin\theta) = r\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + r\sin\theta \underset{\sim}{j} $
$ \underset{\sim}{v} = \int \underset{\sim}{a} \; dt$
$ \underset{\sim}{s} = \int \underset{\sim}{v} \; dt$
$\text{Initial velocity of a vector } = \underset{\sim}{v} = v\cos\theta \underset{\sim}{i} + v \sin \theta \underset{\sim}{j} \text{ where v is the initial speed, a scalar}$
$\text{acceleration due to gravity } = \underset{\sim}{a} = -g\underset{\sim}{j}$
$\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{u}$
$(\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v}) + \underset{\sim}{w} = \underset{\sim}{u} + (\underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{w} )$
$\underset{\sim}{u} + 0 = \underset{\sim}{u}$
$|\underset{\sim}{u} + \underset{\sim}{v}| \le |\underset{\sim}{u}| + |\underset{\sim}{v}|$
$|r| = \sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} = x_1x_2 + y_1y_2 + z_1z_2 = |\underset{\sim}{u}|\underset{\sim}{v}| \cos \theta$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} = \underset{\sim}{v} . \underset{\sim}{u}$
$\underset{\sim}{u} . (\underset{\sim}{v} +\underset{\sim}{w}) = \underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{v} + \underset{\sim}{u} . \underset{\sim}{w}$
$r = \underset{\sim}{a} + \lambda \underset{\sim}{b}$

Working with Combinatorics #


Concepts #

  • arrangements
  • fundamental counting principle, also known as the multiplication principle
  • pigeonhole principle
  • generalised pigeonhole principle
  • ordered selections
  • unordered selections
  • factorial
  • permutations
  • combinations
  • binomial expansion
  • Pascal’s triangle and binomial coefficients
  • Pascal’s triangle identity

Notes #

  • $ n!$ is the number of ways of selecting n objects with no replacement or repetition. Order is important.

  • Permutations = ordered

  • $^nP_r$ is the number of ways of making an ordered selection or r objects from a total of n objects.

$\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$
$\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$
$\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x \text{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$
$\tan(\tan^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$
$\tan^{-1}(\tan x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $
$\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $
$\tan^{-1}(-x) = -\tan^{-1}x $
$\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$
$\sin(A-B) = \sin A \cos B - \cos A \sin B$
$\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$
$\cos(A-B) = \cos A \cos B + \sin A \sin B$
$\tan(A+B) = \dfrac{\tan A + \tan B}{1-\tan A \tan B}$
$\tan(A-B) = \dfrac{\tan A - \tan B}{1+\tan A \tan B}$
$\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$
$\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$
$\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$
$\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$
$\tan 2A = \dfrac{2\tan A}{1-\tan^2 A}$
$ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$ \tan A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$
$\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]$
$\sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]$
$\cos A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]$

Gradients and tangents #

A function y=f(x) is differentiable at a point x= a if its graph is

Proof by Mathematical Induction #


Notes #

  • Can be utilised to prove a statement true for all positive integers, n

  • Step 1: Show that the statement is true for n=1

  • Step 2: Assume that the statement is true for some positive integer n = k

  • Step 3: Using the assumption prove that the statement is also true for the next integer n=k+1

  • Conclusion: State why the statement is true for all positive integers $n \ge 1$ Don’t forget this!

$S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
$S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

$P(E) = \dfrac{\text{Number of ways an event can occur}}{\text{Total number of possible outcomes}}$
$^n P_r = \dfrac{n!}{(n-r)!}$
$0! = 1$
$^n P_n = n!$
$^n P_0 = 1$
Permutations with repeated objects: $\dfrac{n!}{a!b!c!}$ where $a+b+c+... \leq n$
$^nC_r = \dfrac{^n P_r}{r!}$
$(^n_r) = ^n C _r = \dfrac{n!}{r!(n-r)!}$
$ ^n C _0 = (^n_0) = 1 $
$ ^n C _n = (^n_n) = 1 $
$ ^n C _r = ^nC_{n-r} $
$ (x+a)^n = x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a+...+(^n_r)x^{n-r}a^r+...a^n $
$ (x+a)^n = (^n_0)x^n + (^n_1)x^{n-1}a + (^n_2)x^{n-2}a^2 + (^n_3)x^{n-3}a^3+...+(^n_k)x^{n-k}a^k+...+(^n_n)a^n $
$ ^n C _k = ^{n-1}C_{k-1} + ^{n-1}C_k $

Notes #

  • $^nP_r$ is the number of ways of making an ordered selection or r objects from a total of n objects.

$A = P(1+r)^n$
$ T_n = T_{n-1} + d $
$T_n = a + (n-1)d$
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}[2a + (n-1)d] = \dfrac{n}{2}(a+l)$
$T_n = rT_{n-1}$
$T_n = ar^{n-1}$
$S_n = \dfrac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} = \dfrac{a(r^n-1)}{r-1},\ \ r \neq 1$
$S=\dfrac{a}{1-r},\ \ |r|<1$

$\tan(A+B) = \dfrac{\tan A + \tan B}{1-\tan A \tan B}$
$\tan(A-B) = \dfrac{\tan A - \tan B}{1+\tan A \tan B}$
$\sin 2A = 2 \sin A \cos A$
$\cos 2A = \cos^2 A - \sin^2 A$
$\cos 2A = 2 \cos^2 A -1$
$\cos 2A = 1 - 2 \sin^2 A$
$\tan 2A = \dfrac{2\tan A}{1-\tan^2 A}$
$ \sin A = \dfrac{2t}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$ \cos A = \dfrac{1-t^2}{1+t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$ \tan A = \dfrac{2t}{1-t^2} \text{, where t }=\tan \dfrac{A}{2}$
$\cos A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) + \cos(A+B)]$
$\sin A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\cos(A-B) - \cos(A+B)]$
$\sin A \cos B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) + \sin(A-B)]$
$\cos A \sin B = \dfrac{1}{2}[\sin(A+B) - \sin(A-B)]$
$a \sin x + b \cos x = r \sin(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$
$a \sin x - b \cos x = r \sin(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$
$a \cos x + b \sin x = r \cos(x - \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$
$a \cos x - b \sin x = r \cos(x + \alpha) \text{, where } r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} \text { and } \tan \alpha = \dfrac{b}{a}$

$\tan A=\dfrac{opp}{adj}$
$\dfrac{a}{\sin A} = \dfrac{b}{\sin B} = \dfrac{c}{\sin C} $
$c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab \cos C$
$A = \dfrac{1}{2} ab \sin C$
$\sin (180^\circ - \theta) = \sin \theta $
$\cos (180 ^\circ - \theta) = - \cos \theta $
$\tan (180 ^\circ - \theta) = - \tan \theta $
$l=r\theta$
$A=\dfrac{1}{2}r^2 \theta$
$\sec A = \dfrac{1}{\cos A}, \cos A \ne 0$
$\text{cosec } A = \dfrac{1}{\sin A}, \sin A \ne 0$
$\cot A = \dfrac{\cos A}{\sin A}, \sin A \ne 0$
$\cos^2 x+\sin^2 x = 1$
$1+\tan^2 x = \sec^2 x$
$\cot^2 x+1 = \text{cosec }^2 x$
$\tan x = \dfrac{\sin x}{\cos x}, cos x \ne 0$
$\sin \theta = \cos (90^{\circ} - \theta)$
$\cos \theta = \sin (90^{\circ} - \theta)$
$\tan \theta = \cot (90^{\circ} - \theta)$
$\cot \theta = \tan (90^{\circ} - \theta)$
$\sec \theta = \text{cosec } (90^{\circ} - \theta)$
$\text{cosec } \theta = \sec (90^{\circ} - \theta)$
$\sin(\sin^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$
$\sin^{-1}(\sin x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} \le x \le \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\cos(\cos^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -1 \le x \le 1$
$\cos^{-1}(\cos x) = x \text{, for } 0 \le x \le \pi$
$\tan(\tan^{-1} x) = x \text{, for } -\infty < x < \infty$
$\tan^{-1}(\tan x) = x \text{, for } -\dfrac{\pi}{2} < x < \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
$\sin^{-1}(-x) = -\sin^{-1}x $
$\cos^{-1}(-x) = \pi -\cos^{-1}x $
$\tan^{-1}(-x) = -\tan^{-1}x $
$\sin^{-1}x + \cos^{-1}x = \dfrac{\pi}{2}$
